SafetyInspectionBy: Sutter County Fire Dept., Oswald/Tudor Station

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0  Facility Accidental Release Policy
The owners, management, and employees of the Growers Ag Service Yuba City Facility (Facility) located at 2100 Everglade Road, Yuba City, Califonria, 95993 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of aqua ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  A detailed emergency reponse plan has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

2.0  Facility Information
The primary activity at the Facility is the storage and sale of fertilizers and the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.  Aqua ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. Aqua ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 27,000-gallon aboveground storage tank.  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 204,500 pounds of 24% solution. 

3.0 Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios
The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the aqua ammonia storage tank filled to the greatest amount.  This scenario would release 204,500 pounds of aqua ammonia within the secondary containment dike.

The alternative release scenario, based on a more plausible potential incident, is the release from a transfer hose break with an increased wind speed and atmosheric stability class "D".

4.0  Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Facility implements the provisions of the "Safety Requirements for Storage and Handling Anhydrous Ammonia, K61.1" published by the American National Standards Institute, inc.; the California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Subchapter 1, "Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders"; and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29CFR1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" as they apply to aqua ammonia st

orage and handling systems.

5.0  Five-year Accident History
The Facility has not had an accidental release of aqua ammonia in the past five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.

6.0  Emergency Response Program
The Facility has developed an emergency response program in accordance with OSHA 29CFR1910.38 and Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code.

7.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safetty
Safety improvements are an on-going process at the Facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the aqua ammonia process at the Facility will be implemented as needed.
